abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the Kurunegala and
            Second Rural Development Project for Sri Lanka. It assesses
            the outcome, impact, and sustainability of the major
            productive components of the two projects. From a
            quantitative and qualitative viewpoint, it found the
            projects' performance to be mixed. The ERRs (Economic
            Rate for Return) for the productive components were
            generally below the traditional cutoff point for a
            satisfactory rating. In addition, the quality of the initial
            rehabilitation works was poor and the subsequent O&M
            (Operation and Maintenance) insufficient. The primary
            problems behind the poor performance were: 1) overly
            optimistic SAR targets; 2) over-attribution of production
            increases to project actions; and 3) lack of beneficiary
            involvement, poor supervision, and an absence of
            transitional planning. Despite these shortcomings, some
            success did emerge. First, paddy yields in the small
            irrigation schemes rehabilitated under the projects proved
            to be above average for the districts and had increased more
            rapidly than in the country as a whole. Second, the
            infrastructure projects provided significant benefits.
            Lastly, the line agencies involved in implementing the
            projects expanded their implementation capacity
            considerably. Overall, the impact of the projects can be
            considered marginally satisfactory.
